Utterance: Hi there! It’s great to see you again. How has your week been?
Hey, Ellie. It’s been alright, I guess. I tried that pause technique we talked about.
That’s fantastic! How did it go for you?
Honestly, it was a mixed bag. There were moments when I remembered to pause, and others where I forgot completely.
That’s completely normal! It’s all part of the learning process. Can you share a specific situation where you used the technique?
Yeah, there was a moment when I was playing video games with friends, and one of them made a joke about my skills. I felt that anger creeping in, but I took a breath and paused.
That’s a great example! How did your friends respond when you took that moment?
They were surprised at first, but then I just laughed it off instead of flipping out. It felt good.
That’s a wonderful outcome! It sounds like you were able to redirect the situation positively. What do you think helped you remember to pause in that moment?
I think I was just really aware of how I didn’t want to react like I used to. It was like I had a little voice in my head reminding me.
That awareness is key! It shows that you’re making progress. Were there any situations where you didn’t remember to pause?
Yeah, there was one time when I got really mad at my roommate over something dumb. I just exploded.
It’s okay to have those moments too. What do you think triggered that anger?
It was just a buildup of stuff. I felt like he wasn’t respecting my space, and it just boiled over.
It sounds like there might be some underlying feelings there. Have you had a chance to talk to your roommate about it since that incident?
No, not yet. I’m kind of avoiding it because I feel embarrassed.
That’s understandable. However, addressing it could help clear the air. Would you like to discuss how you might approach that conversation?
Yeah, I think I need to. I don’t want to keep feeling this way.
That’s a great mindset. How about starting with expressing how you felt during that moment? You could say something like, “I felt overwhelmed when…”
That sounds good. I’ll try that.
Excellent! Remember, it’s okay to express your feelings. It can lead to a better understanding between you both. Is there anything else you’d like to work on today?
I think I want to dive more into why I get angry so easily. I want to understand it better.
That’s a valuable insight. Let’s explore that. Can you think of any patterns or situations that often lead to your anger?
I guess it’s mostly when I feel disrespected or ignored. Like I’m not being taken seriously.
That’s an important realization. Feeling disrespected can trigger strong emotions. Have you experienced that feeling in other relationships or situations?
Yeah, definitely. It’s not just with my roommate. It’s happened with my wife too.
That connection is significant. It might help to explore how those feelings have influenced your relationships. Would you like to share an example?
Well, there were times when I thought she wasn’t listening to me, and I’d just blow up. I didn’t mean to, but it just happened.
It’s understandable that those feelings can surface in intimate relationships. How do you think you might address that moving forward?
I guess I need to communicate better. Instead of just reacting, I need to express how I feel before it escalates.
That’s a great insight! Communication is key. Would you like to set a goal for yourself regarding this?
Yeah, I want to try to talk to my roommate and be more open with my feelings. I’ll also work on expressing myself to others before getting angry.
That sounds like a solid plan! I’m proud of you for wanting to take these steps. Remember, it’s a journey, and you’re making progress.
Thanks, Ellie. I appreciate your help.
You’re very welcome! I’m looking forward to hearing about your experiences next time. Take care!
Bye, Ellie!
Bye for now!
